history.content: I did this my second semester of freshman year as well. It is tough, you will be studying a ton (I estimate working >80hrs/week), but it is doable and I would recommend you do it if you have an A level understanding of 61a and 16a.

children.subject: Would recommend a lighter academic schedule and filling that free time with *something* else. Anything else. As a graduate student looking back, I wish I had not destroyed myself some semesters and this is an example of a schedule where you're just not going to enjoy yourself for much of the semester. Also, taking 70 after EE16B should make it more manageable in terms of mathematical maturity as well.

I would very strongly suggest taking all three if you are already leaning towards it and are doing well (you mention very well) in ee16a and cs61a. Course load / experience differs per student, but I took all three freshman year spring (with a breadth, decal, and club) along with a bunch of friends, and we all found it manageable. All three classes are great and I thoroughly enjoyed that semester (it helped that I had a good homework/study group for ee16b and cs70). That said, if you only had to take two, I would advise taking cs70 and cs61b (as ee16b is not that relevant for non-ee people).

As an added note, my methodology freshmen/sophomore year was to slowly push my self academically until I found my limit. You can surprise yourself with how much you can handle/enjoy, so I would suggest trying to find your limit and living at that limit for the rest of college sooner rather than later.

history.content:
Is this doable? I was hoping to get more feedback than I could find in the old posts on this schedule.

I'm currently an intended L&S CS freshman. I'm taking ee16a and cs61a, and I've done very well so far. I also feel like I have a lot of free time. Despite that, do you think taking these classes (with just a decal or a seminar) would be a bad idea if I'm looking to keep my GPA up?

I have no prior experience with cs70 or ee16b material; I'm familiar but not comfortable with most of the topics in 61b. I'm leaning toward taking all three, but I also don't want to over-burden myself. Any advice? My second choice would be to take only cs70 and cs61b.

Thanks!
history.subject: ee16b, cs61b, cs70?
